newsitem.title: USA: Dollar closes lower in U.S. on late profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Dollar closes lower in U.S. on late profit-taking.

text.p: The dollar ended lower against major currencies Tuesday as a late afternoon nosedive wiped out modest early gains.
Investors sold dollar/mark and sterling/mark to lock in profits after several days of rallying, while a wire service report triggered sales of dollar/yen, currency dealers said.
Market News Service reported an unnamed White House official predicted the persistent U.S.-Japan trade gap would soon begin to widen after months of shrinkage.
The U.S. propensity to import leaves foreigners with a steady supply of dollars to be sold in the currency market.
"That story is probably what got the ball rolling," said James Phoenix, director of foreign exchange sales at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York.
For most of the day the dollar sat just below Tuesday's 33-month high at 112.91 yen. But the late selloff sank the dollar to 112.27/32 yen, down from 112.80/90 at the open.

Against the mark, the dollar fell nearly a pfennig and closed at 1.5252/57 from 1.5332/35 at the open. The dollar also fell to 1.2535/45 Swiss francs from 1.2628/33. The British pound ended higher at $1.5988/95 from $1.5960/70.
Investors sold sterling when it failed to top key technical hurdles at 2.45 marks, a 22-month high, and $1.60.
The mark and Swiss franc powered higher against the dollar as a result, dealers said.

"We saw some pretty aggressive dollar selling by investment banks. Some people had gotten long the dollar in the morning, but when there was no follow-through buying, they got nervous," said Stephen Jury, chief dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.

The dollar climbed against the yen in early trade after Japan reported its index of leading economic indicators plunged to 33.3 in August from 77.8 in July--well below the 50.0 level deemed the boundary between boom and bust.
That suggests the Bank of Japan will keep interest rates low in coming months, which would bolster the dollar by enhancing the relative value of assets priced in dollars.

"The Japanese economy is still struggling. The dollar should continue to move gradually higher against the yen over the next month or so," said Tadatoshi Taso, chief dealer at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York.
The mark also got an early boost as Germany began the road show of its planned privatization of the state-owned telephone company, Deutsche Telekom.
The sale would raise about 18 billion marks and some investors bet the mark would rise as would-be Telekom buyers sell other currencies for marks in preparation, dealers said.
"Today's move was very much a move of the mark against sterling and the yen. That also touched off some sales of dollars for marks," said Chris Adair, currency trader at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
In other trade, the dollar fell to Canadian $1.3452/57 from C$1.3469/74. The Australian dollar fell to $0.7942/47 from, $0.7960/65.
